caseTitle: IN THE MATTER OF JOSEPH EDWARD BINEY (DECEASED), FREDERICK EMMANUEL EKUBAN, JOSEPH EMANUEL ADDO, JOSEPH ALPHEUS VINCENT CANN AND JOHN SAMUEL AKYIANU, & Co
summary: This 1939 West African Court of Appeal decision addressed a motion to approve sureties for an appeal to the Privy Council. The appellant, Kwami Baisie, sought to vary an order requiring service of notice on all respondents, having only served one respondent and one solicitor. The court held that under the West African Court of Appeal Rules (1937), service on a party's solicitor is not equivalent to service on the party itself, and strict compliance with service requirements was necessary. As the condition of service on all respondents was not met, the application was refused with costs assessed at Â£1 10s. 6d.
legalKeywords: West African Court of Appeal Rules
citations: West African Court of Appeal Rules (1937)
rationaleHighlights: Service on solicitor not equivalent to service on party
Strict compliance with court orders required
Rules do not permit substituted service by default
Conditional leave subject to full compliance
Notice must be served on all respondents
confidenceNotes: High confidence; information directly extracted from primary legal document with clear judicial reasoning and procedural context.
